content.title: Vertigo Differential Diagnosis
content.summary: Vertigo is the illusion of rotational movement, most commonly caused by peripheral vestibular disorders (BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's) or central causes (stroke, tumor). The critical distinction is peripheral vs central, as central vertigo may indicate life-threatening pathology. The HINTS exam is more sensitive than MRI for detecting posterior circulation stroke in acute vestibular syndrome.
key_points: Vertigo = illusion of rotation; distinguish from lightheadedness/presyncope/disequilibrium
Peripheral (80%): BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's - generally benign
Central (20%): Stroke, MS, tumor - potentially life-threatening
HINTS exam: Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew - distinguishes central from peripheral
BPPV: Brief (<1 min), positional, Dix-Hallpike positive, Epley maneuver curative
Vestibular neuritis: Acute onset, continuous >24 hours, no hearing loss
content.statement: Vertigo differential diagnosis centers on distinguishing benign peripheral causes (BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's) from dangerous central causes (stroke, tumor) using history, timing, triggers, and the HINTS exam.

explanation.intuition: Think of the balance system as having peripheral sensors (inner ear) and a central processor (brainstem/cerebellum). Peripheral vertigo means a sensor is malfunctioning - the brain gets confused signals from one ear. Central vertigo means the processor is damaged - the brain can't interpret signals correctly. Peripheral problems are usually benign; central problems can be life-threatening.
explanation.key_insight: The HINTS exam is MORE SENSITIVE than early MRI for detecting posterior circulation stroke. In acute vestibular syndrome (AVS), a 'central' HINTS (normal head impulse, direction-changing nystagmus, or skew deviation) has 96-100% sensitivity for stroke. Don't rely on MRI to rule out stroke in the first 24-48 hours.
explanation.technical_details: Head Impulse Test: examines VOR; abnormal (corrective saccade) = peripheral. Nystagmus: unidirectional horizontal = peripheral; direction-changing or vertical = central. Test of Skew: vertical misalignment = central (skew deviation indicates brainstem lesion). HINTS sensitivity >96% vs MRI ~80% in first 24 hours.

definitions_glossary.vertigo: Illusion of rotational movement of self or environment
definitions_glossary.peripheral_vertigo: Vertigo from labyrinth or vestibular nerve dysfunction
definitions_glossary.central_vertigo: Vertigo from brainstem or cerebellar dysfunction
definitions_glossary.BPPV: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo - otoconia in semicircular canals
definitions_glossary.vestibular_neuritis: Acute peripheral vestibulopathy, usually viral, without hearing loss
definitions_glossary.labyrinthitis: Vestibular neuritis with hearing loss (cochlear involvement)
definitions_glossary.HINTS_exam: Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew - bedside stroke screening
definitions_glossary.head_impulse_test: Tests vestibulo-ocular reflex; abnormal = peripheral cause
definitions_glossary.Dix_Hallpike: Provocative maneuver for posterior canal BPPV
definitions_glossary.Epley_maneuver: Canalith repositioning for posterior canal BPPV
definitions_glossary.nystagmus: Involuntary rhythmic eye movements; slow phase indicates lesion side
definitions_glossary.skew_deviation: Vertical misalignment of eyes; indicates central lesion

pathophysiology.mechanism: Vertigo results from asymmetric vestibular input - one side signals movement while the other doesn't, creating mismatch interpreted as rotation

peripheral_causes.BPPV: Otoconia displaced into semicircular canals; head movement causes abnormal cupula stimulation
peripheral_causes.vestibular_neuritis: Viral inflammation of vestibular nerve; sudden unilateral vestibular loss
peripheral_causes.Meniere: Endolymphatic hydrops; episodic attacks with hearing loss
peripheral_causes.labyrinthitis: Infection involving both vestibular and cochlear portions

central_causes.stroke: Posterior circulation (PICA, AICA, vertebral) affecting brainstem/cerebellum

timing_and_triggers.seconds_positional: BPPV - triggered by head position change

HINTS_exam_interpretation.peripheral_pattern: Abnormal head impulse + unidirectional nystagmus + no skew = SAFE
HINTS_exam_interpretation.central_pattern: Normal head impulse OR direction-changing nystagmus OR skew = DANGEROUS
HINTS_exam_interpretation.key_point: Only apply to ACUTE vestibular syndrome (continuous vertigo >24 hours)

associated_symptoms.hearing_loss: Meniere, labyrinthitis, AICA stroke, vestibular schwannoma
associated_symptoms.neurological_deficits: Central cause - limb ataxia, dysarthria, diplopia

differential_diagnosis: Vestibular neuritis (acute, continuous, no hearing loss)
Meniere disease (episodic, hearing loss, tinnitus, fullness)
Vestibular migraine (headache history, photophobia, variable duration)
Posterior circulation stroke (central HINTS, risk factors, deficits)
Vestibular schwannoma (progressive hearing loss, MRI with contrast)
Multiple sclerosis (young patient, other CNS symptoms)

BPPV.diagnosis: Dix-Hallpike maneuver (posterior canal); supine roll test (horizontal canal)
BPPV.treatment: Epley maneuver (posterior); Barbecue roll (horizontal); 80-90% cure rate

vestibular_neuritis.acute: Vestibular suppressants (meclizine, diazepam) for 2-3 days only
vestibular_neuritis.steroids: May accelerate recovery if given within 72 hours
vestibular_neuritis.vestibular_rehab: Essential for long-term recovery; promotes central compensation

central_vertigo.stroke: Thrombolytics if eligible; aspirin, anticoagulation based on etiology
central_vertigo.imaging: MRI with DWI essential; CT may miss posterior fossa stroke
central_vertigo.admission: Cerebellar stroke can lead to herniation from edema

definition.@value: A systematic approach to distinguishing benign peripheral vestibular causes of vertigo from dangerous central causes using clinical features and the HINTS examination

scopeNote.@value: Covers differential diagnosis, HINTS exam, and management of vertigo

learning_objectives: Distinguish vertigo from other types of dizziness (presyncope, disequilibrium)
Categorize vertigo causes by timing and triggers
Perform and interpret the HINTS examination
Recognize red flags for central vertigo
Apply appropriate treatment for BPPV and vestibular neuritis
clinical_pearls: HINTS is more sensitive than MRI in first 24-48 hours for posterior fossa stroke
BPPV: brief (<1 min), positional, Dix-Hallpike positive, Epley curative
Normal head impulse in acute vestibular syndrome = worry about stroke
Vestibular suppressants delay compensation - limit use to 2-3 days
Hearing loss with vertigo: think AICA stroke, Meniere, or labyrinthitis
common_misconceptions: Negative MRI rules out stroke - early MRI misses 20% of posterior circulation strokes
All vertigo with nausea is labyrinthitis - BPPV also causes nausea
Antiemetics help vertigo - they help nausea but don't treat underlying cause
